author: By Neil Genzlinger
title: Andy González, Prolific Latin Jazz Bassist, Is Dead at 69
description: A busy studio musician, he was also a key part of two influential groups: the Fort Apache Band, which he founded with his brother Jerry, and Libre.
content: Andy González, one of the great bassists in Latin jazz, who in a career that stretched more than four decades played with numerous influential groups — notably the Fort Apache Band, which he formed with his brother Jerry — died on Thursday in the Bronx. He was 69.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kirk Semple and Azam Ahmed
title: Murder Rates Were Staggering. The Virus Has Brought Some Quiet, for Now.
description: With businesses and commercial activity all but shut down, there are fewer people outdoors, making the streets easier to police and less likely to be zones of criminal opportunity and conflict.
content: MEXICO CITY — In El Salvador, the number of murders plunged by nearly half between February and March. Neighboring Honduras has also seen a falloff in killings in recent weeks, as has Colombia and the most populous state in Mexico.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ross Douthat
title: The Pandemic and the Will of God
description: The purpose of suffering may be mysterious, but the search for meaning is obligatory.
content: Notwithstanding the fond hopes of our president, the pandemic that spread around the world during the Christian season of Lent isn’t ending miraculously as Good Friday gives way to Easter Sunday. The liturgical calendar has turned, but the churches remain empty, and the long Lent imposed by the coronavirus will continue for many months to come.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nicholas Kristof
title: Life and Death in the ‘Hot Zone’
description: “If people saw this, they would stay home.” What the war against the coronavirus looks like inside two Bronx hospitals.
content: This is not a time to die.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mark Landler
title: How a Pandemic Rescued the Political Image of Ireland’s Leader
description: Leo Varadkar is winning praise after reactivating his registration as a medical doctor and heading to the coronavirus front lines.
content: LONDON — Just two months ago, Ireland’s leader, Leo Varadkar, was a spent force in Irish politics: a trailblazing prime minister whose failure to solve Ireland’s housing crisis frustrated voters and whose aloof style left them cold. In a three-way Parliamentary race in February, his party finished last.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Simon Critchley
title: To Philosophize Is to Learn How to Die
description: Facing death can be a key to our liberation and survival.
content: We’re scared. We’re on edge, unable to concentrate. We can’t find focus. Our minds flit and float around flealike from one update to the next. We follow the news, because we feel we should. And then we wish we hadn’t, because it’s terrifying and sad. Daytime naps seem involuntary and fitful. Sleep will often not descend. But when it does, we sometimes wake, in a mortal panic, with hypochondriac symptoms we feel to be real but we know are not; and then we feel selfishly stupid for having them in the first place. We take our temperature. We wait. We take it again. It goes on. Feelings of powerlessness and ennui slide into impotent rage at what is being done and, most of all, what is not being done, or is being done poorly, irresponsibly, dishonestly.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Quotation of the Day: Pandemic Scrambles Supply Chains
description: Quotation of the Day for Saturday, April 11, 2020.
content: “There’s no shortage of calories available, it’s just they’re in the wrong size bag.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sarah Firshein
title: Help! The Coronavirus Struck and I Want a Refund
description: In this week’s column, Sarah Firshein investigates the ever-changing refund policies offered by travel companies.
content: Travel and travel planning are being disrupted by the worldwide spread of the coronavirus. For the latest updates, read The New York Times’s Covid-19 coverage here.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Chicken! Lemon! Artichokes!
description: Make Joan Nathan’s chicken recipe, Melissa Clark’s adaptable lemony asparagus salad, and many others.
content: The week’s most popular dishes include Joan Nathan’s recipe for chicken with artichokes and lemon (above); Alison Roman’s matzo ball soup; and Melissa Clark’s adaptable lemony asparagus salad. Find more recipes in the collection below.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Amy Harmon
title: ‘You Could Lick the Benches’: Life for the First Wave of U.S. Survivors
description: As the rest of the nation shelters in place, the first Americans to recover from the virus test drive immunity.
content: Christy Karras and her husband received a tantalizing text the other day from friends they had not seen since February, when all four were among the first people in the United States to be sickened by the new coronavirus.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By John Schwartz
title: S. Fred Singer, a Leading Climate Change Contrarian, Dies at 95
description: Derided as a “Merchant of Doubt,” he spent decades trying to refute the evidence of global warming and other environmental risks.
content: S. Fred Singer, a physicist whose efforts to refute established climate science earned him the enmity of experts, died on April 6 at a nursing facility in Rockville, Md. He was 95.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ronda Kaysen
title: My Landlord Won’t Let Me Break My Lease. What Can I Do?
description: In a normal housing market, landlords are usually able to re-rent apartments and spare tenants a penalty. But these are not normal times.
content: Q: My husband and I rent a market-rate apartment in Brooklyn, with a lease that expires in November. I’m seven months pregnant and terrified of delivering in the city during the coronavirus pandemic. We want to break our lease and stay with my parents upstate since we’re both working remotely anyway. But our landlord says unless we can find someone to take over the lease, he won’t let us out of it. What can we do?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christopher Healy
title: ‘Wayside School’ Is Back, With Payoffs to Jokes That Began 40 Years Ago
description: Of all the volumes of Louis Sachar’s absurd and absurdist series, this newest installment reads most like a novel, with one prominent plotline tying most of the chapters together.
content: When an author advises — as Louis Sachar does in the foreword to WAYSIDE SCHOOL BENEATH THE CLOUD OF DOOM (Harper/HarperCollins, 192 pp., $17.99; ages 8 to 12), the fourth volume of his Wayside School series — that “to fully enjoy this book, you should read the other three first,” believe him. This absurd and absurdist series, about a 30-story elementary school with one classroom on each floor, has seen a new addition only once every decade or two since its inception in 1978, but it has still generated enough fan-feeding mythology to fill its own wiki. While it’s certainly not impossible for “Cloud of Doom” to serve as an introduction for newcomers, it is eminently more enjoyable as a follow-up.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Corrections: April 11, 2020
description: Corrections that appeared in print on Saturday, April 11, 2020.
content: An article on Friday about an introduction to silent comedies described incorrectly the newspaper a woman is reading in “Seven Chances.” The paper uses Hebrew lettering; it is not entirely in Hebrew.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sara Aridi
title: What’s on TV Saturday: ‘It Chapter Two’ and ‘The Clark Sisters’
description: Pennywise haunts the small screen in the “It” sequel, while a biopic of a gospel group debuts on Lifetime.
content: IT CHAPTER TWO (2019) 8 p.m. on HBO; stream on HBO platforms. Stephen King fans welcomed the director Andy Muschietti’s film adaptation of the 1986 novel “It” in 2017. That led to led this sequel, which picks up 27 years after the events of the first movie. The seven friends of the Losers Club reunite in their picturesque town of Derry, Me. All have seemingly moved on from their traumas involving It — the supernatural killer that takes the form of Pennywise the clown (Bill Skarsgard) — except for Mike (Isaiah Mustafa), who has been obsessively researching ways to stop It for good. Flashbacks of the friends’ encounters with It resurface from years ago, and each of them have to confront demons that were long buried. Some critics praised the cast — which also includes Jessica Chastain, Bill Hader, James McAvoy, Jay Ryan, James Ransone and Andy Bean — but said the scares are underwhelming.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Franz Lidz
title: At the Sourdough Library, With Some Very Old Mothers
description: Some starters never die, they just get filed away here.
content: In these housebound times, Americans have gone stark baking mad. Shut-ins are channeling their anxieties into pandemic pastries and quarantine cookies, some with icing piped in the shape of surgical masks, others frosted with the face of Dr. Anthony Fauci. Baking essentials such as yeast and flour are in short supply, and Google searches for bread recipes are on the rise, so to speak.
source.name: The New York Times

title: A Bouncer’s Advice for Breaking Up Sibling Fights
description: And more guidance on Easter, Passover and working from home.
content: We had our first Zoom Seder this week. I had never hosted Passover in my home, so we had zero essentials and, though I tried to get what I could at the store, a lamb shank is not easy to come by in this particular moment. So, my kids drew the big bone and the gefilte fish on a piece of paper, and my 3-year-old insisted on eating a tortilla with ketchup instead of matzo. We read from a PDF Haggadah I found on Reform Judaism dot org. And you know what? It was still pretty special.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Joseph Berger
title: Dario Gabbai, a Final Witness to Auschwitz, Is Dead at 97
description: He was among the last Sonderkommandos, prisoners forced by the Nazis to herd fellow inmates into the gas chambers.
content: Of all the jobs that Jewish slave laborers had to perform at the Auschwitz-Birkenau concentration camp in Poland, none perhaps was more despised than that of Sonderkommando — a member of the “special unit” that instructed men, women and children to undress for the gas chambers, and dragged their bodies to the crematories.
source.name: The New York Times

title: A Bit of Relief: ‘Soup Is Soup’
description: A granddaughter learns cooking secrets from her grandma — over FaceTime.
content: Listen and subscribe to our podcast from your mobile device:Via Apple Podcasts | Via Spotify | Via Stitcher
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lauren Leatherby and David Gelles
title: How the Virus Transformed the Way Americans Spend Their Money
description: Airlines and movie theaters are hurting. Grocery stores and streaming services are raking it in.
content: Airlines and movie theaters are hurting. Grocery stores and streaming services are raking it in.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tracey Tully
title: He Beat Coronavirus. Now His Blood May Help Save Lives.
description: A New Jersey doctor’s blood was found to have high levels of virus antibodies. Researchers plan to use it to treat other patients.
content: In mid-March, Hackensack University Medical Center in New Jersey announced the first coronavirus-linked death in the Northeast. Since then, there have been more than 16,000 virus-related deaths in the United States, and the toll grows by the hour.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Amy Julia Harris, John Leland and Tracey Tully
title: Nearly 2,000 Dead as Coronavirus Ravages Nursing Homes in N.Y. Region
description: The facilities knew that frail and aging residents were especially vulnerable to the outbreak, but they were unable to stop it.
content: At Crown Heights Center for Nursing and Rehabilitation in Brooklyn, workers said they had to convert a room into a makeshift morgue after more than 15 residents died of the coronavirus, and funeral homes could not handle all the bodies.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Coronavirus Live Updates: Total Number of Confirmed Deaths in U.S. Surpasses Italy
description: For the first time, the government has declared all 50 states a major disaster for the same event. Some pastors plan to hold Easter services despite stay-at-home guidance.
content: This briefing has ended. Follow our global coverage of the coronavirus epidemic.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By John Branch
title: Whoosh! That Car That Just Soared by Might Be Heading for the Coast
description: With far less traffic thanks to coronavirus-induced quarantines, drivers are pushing down hard on their accelerators. Tickets, and records, are the result.
content: NOVATO, Calif. — A white 2019 Audi A8 L sedan with extra fuel tanks in the trunk pulled away from a Midtown Manhattan parking garage late last Saturday night. A driver on a high-speed mission aimed the car west and hit the accelerator.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Carl Hulse
title: Does a Dept. of Pandemics Sound Odd? Homeland Security Once Did, Too
description: Past crises have prompted major federal overhauls. Failings in the government handling of the coronavirus outbreak are likely to spur calls for another one.
content: WASHINGTON — Exactly one month after the Sept. 11, 2001, attacks, two senior senators proposed the creation of an entirely new government department that would pull together the diverse, often competitive federal agencies whose lack of communication and coordination left the nation exposed to deadly terrorism on American soil. It became the Department of Homeland Security.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alexander Burns
title: Biden and Cuomo: Friends, Allies and Supporting Players No Longer
description: A personal friendship has grown into a crucial political alliance as the two men have emerged as pillars of the Democratic Party in a national crisis.
content: In late July of 2015, Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr. traversed the state of New York with Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo, ending the day in Queens, where they announced plans to rebuild La Guardia Airport. On a flight with Mr. Cuomo aboard Air Force Two, Mr. Biden broached a delicate subject: his own interest in the presidency.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alexa Weibel
title: Missing an Ingredient? Here’s What You Can Use Instead
description: Don’t worry: You probably have something in your kitchen that will work. It might even improve the recipe.
content: The most important skill in the kitchen — and, arguably, life — is adaptability. The list below, which is by no means comprehensive, is meant to help you replace ingredients with confidence. Every alternative listed may not work in every case, especially when it comes to baking, but if you consider the ingredient’s texture, flavor and cook time, and make decisions according to taste, you’ll greatly expand your options — and you may even end up with a dish you like better than the original.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Keith Bradsher
title: China Delays Mask and Ventilator Exports After Quality Complaints
description: Chinese customs officials, facing accusations from Europe that some medical supplies have been defective, say they will inspect every shipment.
content: BEIJING — Chinese officials have begun inspecting every shipment of N95 respirators, ventilators and other medical supplies for quality issues before export, a policy likely to delay the arrival of critical gear at hospitals around the world that are struggling to cope with the coronavirus pandemic.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maria Varenikova
title: Chernobyl Wildfires Reignite, Stirring Up Radiation
description: Wildfires are common in the so-called Zone of Alienation around the abandoned Chernobyl plant. A larger-than-typical fire is stirring up radiation, though levels remain normal in Kyiv, the Ukrainian capital.
content: VINNYTSIA, Ukraine — Firefighters have struggled to control wildfires burning through radioactive forest in the abandoned territory around the Chernobyl nuclear plant, where radiation levels are considerably lower than they were immediately after the 1986 accident but still pose risks.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alyson Krueger
title: The Chain Letter Is Back, and Just as Annoying as Before
description: Poems, inspiring quotes, and memories of first cars and kisses are all making the rounds.
content: Rachel Hynes, 35, a financial consultant who lives in the Battery Park neighborhood of Manhattan, woke up on a recent Monday morning to an email from a female colleague she rarely works with.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maria Varenikova
title: Chernobyl Wildfires Reignite, Stirring Up Radiation
description: Wildfires are common in the so-called Zone of Alienation around the abandoned Chernobyl plant. A larger-than-typical fire is stirring up radiation, though levels remain normal in Kyiv, the Ukrainian capital.
content: VINNYTSIA, Ukraine — Firefighters have struggled to control wildfires burning through radioactive forest in the abandoned territory around the Chernobyl nuclear plant, where radiation levels are considerably lower than they were immediately after the 1986 accident but still pose risks.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alyson Krueger
title: The Chain Letter Is Back, and Just as Annoying as Before
description: Poems, inspiring quotes, and memories of first cars and kisses are all making the rounds.
content: Rachel Hynes, 35, a financial consultant who lives in the Battery Park neighborhood of Manhattan, woke up on a recent Monday morning to an email from a female colleague she rarely works with.
source.name: The New York Times

title: A Bouncer’s Advice for Breaking Up Sibling Fights
description: And more guidance on Easter, Passover and working from home.
content: We had our first Zoom Seder this week. I had never hosted Passover in my home, so we had zero essentials and, though I tried to get what I could at the store, a lamb shank is not easy to come by in this particular moment. So, my kids drew the big bone and the gefilte fish on a piece of paper, and my 3-year-old insisted on eating a tortilla with ketchup instead of matzo. We read from a PDF Haggadah I found on Reform Judaism dot org. And you know what? It was still pretty special.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Joseph Berger
title: Dario Gabbai, a Final Witness to Auschwitz, Is Dead at 97
description: He was among the last Sonderkommandos, prisoners forced by the Nazis to herd fellow inmates into the gas chambers.
content: Of all the jobs that Jewish slave laborers had to perform at the Auschwitz-Birkenau concentration camp in Poland, none perhaps was more despised than that of Sonderkommando — a member of the “special unit” that instructed men, women and children to undress for the gas chambers, and dragged their bodies to the crematories.
source.name: The New York Times

title: A Bit of Relief: ‘Soup Is Soup’
description: A granddaughter learns cooking secrets from her grandma — over FaceTime.
content: Listen and subscribe to our podcast from your mobile device:Via Apple Podcasts | Via Spotify | Via Stitcher
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Hannah Beech and Adam Dean
title: 500 Years Ago, This Port Linked East to West. Its Fate Was to Fade Away.
description: Malacca gave birth to the notion of Asian Fusion centuries before it became a culinary trope. Its decline speaks to the promise and perils of globalization.
content: MALACCA, Malaysia — About the fastest moving force these days in the old Portuguese Settlement of Malacca is the sweat trickling down the torsos of the underemployed.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Eric Lipton
title: The ‘Red Dawn’ Emails: 8 Key Exchanges on the Faltering Response to the Coronavirus
description: Experts inside and outside the government identified the threat early on and sought to raise alarms even as President Trump was moving slowly. Read some of what they had to say among themselves at critical moments.
content: WASHINGTON — As the coronavirus emerged and headed toward the United States, an extraordinary conversation was hatched among an elite group of infectious disease doctors and medical experts in the federal government and academic institutions around the nation.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Patricia Mazzei and Frances Robles
title: The Costly Toll of Not Shutting Down Spring Break Earlier
description: People got sick — and some died — after attending crowded parties and theme parks in Florida as the coronavirus spread.
content: MIAMI — You could find Beatriz Diaz at this spring’s Winter Party Festival in Miami Beach, giving out hand sanitizer.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Crystal Martin
title: So Your Hair Is Relaxed …
description: Relaxing your own roots is notoriously difficult to get right and can be damaging to the hair. But you do have options.
content: Much of the conversation surrounding black hair in recent years has been about caring for and styling natural hair, and for good reason. As news spread that relaxers may cause hormone disruptions and other health issues, black women, in droves, began to cut off their relaxed hair and wear their natural texture.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Reed Abelson
title: Dialysis Patients Face Close-Up Risk From Coronavirus
description: As the pandemic sweeps the United States, patients needing kidney dialysis and employees of the clinics worry about keeping the virus at bay in such tight spaces.
content: Mat Risher leaves the safety of his home near Seattle three days a week for dialysis at a clinic, a treatment he cannot live without but one that now most likely increases his risk of exposure to the coronavirus.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jen A. Miller
title: How to Run for 2.5 Days
description: Hint: It helps if you don’t require sleep.
content: Welcome to the Running newsletter! Every Saturday morning, we email runners with news, advice and some motivation to help you get up and running. Sign up here to get it in your inbox.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Caitlin Lovinger
title: Variety: Acrostic
description: Emily Cox and Henry Rathvon, we missed you so.
content: ACROSTIC — Presumably everyone here encountered and survived the last acrostic, which people seemed to find as hard as I did. This is gratifying. So is today’s puzzle, because it’s pleasant and doable, a welcome return to acrostic normalcy that I will take as a sign of things to come in general. Even the passage’s author, Anne Lamott, is a very well-known purveyor of wisdom and comfort in her writing, notably the source of the passage, “Bird by Bird: Some Instructions on Writing and Life.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lenora Todaro
title: A Tragicomic Tale of Wanderlust and the Fur Trade, Told by a Squirrel
description: In Margi Preus’s middle-grade novel “The Littlest Voyageur,” a pesky red squirrel spars with eight men named Jean on a river journey in 18th-century French Canada.
content: The writer E. L. Doctorow — who, in “Ragtime” and other novels, pioneered a new way of presenting historical material in fiction — once said in an interview: “The historian will tell you what happened. The novelist will tell you what it felt like.” This kind of novelist deposits the reader in another era to walk in someone else’s shoes. History plus empathy equals artistry.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Crystal Martin
title: So Your Hair Is Relaxed …
description: Relaxing your own roots is notoriously difficult to get right and can be damaging to the hair. But you do have options.
content: Much of the conversation surrounding black hair in recent years has been about caring for and styling natural hair, and for good reason. As news spread that relaxers may cause hormone disruptions and other health issues, black women, in droves, began to cut off their relaxed hair and wear their natural texture.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emma Goldberg
title: Hospital Chaplains Try to Keep the Faith During the Coronavirus Pandemic
description: They are used to serving as vessels for others’ grief and fear, but the outbreak has changed how they practice their work, and how they feel.
content: The Rev. Leah Klug isn’t a stickler on religious rituals. As a hospital chaplain for Swedish Medical Group in the Seattle area, she makes do with the supplies she can find. Recently, she performed an anointing of the sick with mouthwash, because she didn’t have any oil on hand. She is accustomed to seeking the sacred in sterile rooms, reading psalms above the steady beep of a heart monitor.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Alaska Primary Election Results 2020
description: Results from the Alaska presidential primary election.
content: Results from the Alaska presidential primary election.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Doctors’ Voices in the Coronavirus Pandemic
description: Doctors discuss some of the ethical issues they face, such as should they be required to serve on the front lines, and their own fears.
content: To the Editor:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Bret Stephens
title: Covid-19 and the Big Government Problem
description: What happens when bureaucratic dead weight meets a horseman of the apocalypse?
content: Katie Wilson, a deputy under secretary at the Department of Agriculture in the Obama administration, is the executive director of the Urban School Food Alliance, a nonprofit that works with the country’s largest school districts to improve the quality of student nutrition. Her topmost concern is with the millions of poorer children and their families for whom school meals are essential to diets and budgets alike.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Courtney Mabeus
title: How an Island Oasis Became the Navy’s Coronavirus Epicenter
description: An outbreak aboard an aircraft carrier has left local officials in Guam to contend with the arrival of hundreds of infected sailors, while they also try to protect the island’s population.
content: As the novel coronavirus spread through Asia in January and February, Lourdes Leon Guerrero saw an opportunity for her small island. The governor and her lieutenant appeared in a tourism advertisement promoting Guam as an “island paradise” that was “coronavirus free,” and the video was posted to the government’s official tourism website. “Warm weather and warm smiles are waiting for you here,” Leon Guerrero, who has governed Guam since January 2019, says to the camera.
source.name: The New York Times

author: Video by Alexander Stockton, Zach Goldbaum and Michael Kirby Smith
title: Heartache in the Hot Zone: The Front Line Against Covid-19
description: Nicholas Kristof visits two New York City hospitals and witnesses the heavy toll on medical workers fighting to keep Americans alive.
content: Nicholas Kristof visits two New York City hospitals and witnesses the heavy toll on medical workers fighting to keep Americans alive.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Clifford Krauss
title: As Russia and Saudi Arabia Retreat, U.S. Oil Industry Avoids the Worst
description: Job losses and bankruptcies appear certain, but a deal among producers may put a floor under prices for now.
content: HOUSTON — The American oil industry may have dodged a bullet.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Coronavirus in N.Y.: Cuomo Urges Caution on Reopening State’s Economy
description: Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo also said Mayor Bill de Blasio lacked the authority to close New York City’s schools for the rest of the academic year.
content: Weeks after ordering a shutdown across the state, Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo on Saturday said the efforts were beginning to pay off and the curve of new coronavirus cases was continuing to flatten.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ira Berkow
title: Al Kaline Wondered if He Should Have Been a Doctor
description: The Hall of Fame outfielder, who died Monday, once wondered aloud to our columnist whether playing baseball was worthwhile.
content: Funny how sometimes you remember most saliently a particular instance — perhaps a little thing, an otherwise unnoticed moment — that illuminates, or symbolizes, the whole.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Yaffe-Bellany and Michael Corkery
title: Dumped Milk, Smashed Eggs, Plowed Vegetables: Food Waste of the Pandemic
description: With restaurants, hotels and schools closed, many of the nation’s largest farms are destroying millions of pounds of fresh goods that they can no longer sell.
content: In Wisconsin and Ohio, farmers are dumping thousands of gallons of fresh milk into lagoons and manure pits. An Idaho farmer has dug huge ditches to bury 1 million pounds of onions. And in South Florida, a region that supplies much of the Eastern half of the United States with produce, tractors are crisscrossing bean and cabbage fields, plowing perfectly ripe vegetables back into the soil.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Adam Liptak
title: Fight Over Texas Abortion Ban Reaches Supreme Court
description: State officials say the pandemic requires restricting abortions, while clinics say the state is cynically using the crisis to achieve longstanding goals.
content: WASHINGTON — Abortion providers in Texas asked the Supreme Court on Saturday to let their clinics continue to perform some procedures after a federal appeals court temporarily upheld orders from state officials prohibiting most abortions.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Aimee Ortiz
title: Burning Man Falls Victim to Pandemic
description: Organizers have scrapped plans to build Black Rock City in a Nevada desert this summer. But they hope to create something online.
content: Burning Man, the annual arts event that draws tens of thousands of people to Black Rock Desert and tens of millions of dollars to Northern Nevada’s economy, has joined the list of high-profile gatherings to fall prey to the coronavirus pandemic.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Trip Gabriel
title: How the Virus Crisis Could Help a Red-State Democrat Stay in Office
description: In North Carolina, where the governor’s race is tight, and New Hampshire, where a Republican seeks re-election in a blue-trending state, incumbents could benefit from newfound star power.
content: Gov. Chris Sununu of New Hampshire is ideologically limber, a Republican who favors abortion rights but vetoed a bill banning firearms on school property. At 45, he is one of America’s youngest governors, and a member of a well-known political family. He is also seeking re-election in a state increasingly inhospitable to his party.
source.name: The New York Times

title: India to Extend Lockdown Against Coronavirus, While Spain Eases Work Rules
description: China is delaying medical equipment exports for quality checks. A Times investigation examines President Trump’s delays in facing the crisis. Murders fall in Latin America.
content: This briefing has ended. Read global live updates on the coronavirus here.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maeve Higgins
title: I Don’t Want to Be Here Now and You Can’t Make Me
description: I’m stuck at home with my parents and my new nemesis: a cat. But at least I’m not pregnant!
content: COBH, Ireland — I’m a brown-haired woman and I usually feel fine about it. But in rocky times, existential or personal, my hair is the first problem on my list. The drumbeat starts, and I can’t ignore it. Change your hair, change your hair. I will. As soon as everything goes back to normal and I get home to Brooklyn, I know a Russian lady who will dye my hair a warm red-brown color.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ronen Bergman
title: My Father Didn’t Have Covid-19, but He Almost Died Because of It
description: Dad was fading and the hospital seemed like the most dangerous option. What was I supposed to do?
content: HAIFA, Israel — The E.R. doctor gave me an accusing look: “Clearly the deterioration did not begin today. Why did you bring him in only now? Without medical care, he would not have lasted the night.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Steven Paulikas
title: The World Is Empty Now. How Should We Fill It?
description: The void created by this crisis may be an unexpected gift.
content: My church is empty this Easter. In lieu of greeting the usually joyful parishioners this day, my clergy colleague and I celebrate the ancient rites of our religion six feet apart from each other, as an iPhone live-streams to self-isolated viewers at home.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David W. Blight
title: Trump Reveals the Truth About Voter Suppression
description: The president is the latest in a long line of conservative politicians to see minority voters as a threat.
content: On March 30, the Republican id burst forth when President Trump said that the latest congressional stimulus bill “had things — levels of voting that, if you ever agreed to it, you’d never have a Republican elected in this country again.” Two days later, the Republican House speaker in Georgia, David Ralston, admitted that an expansion of absentee voting would be “extremely devastating to Republicans and conservatives in Georgia.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Peter Baker, Zolan Kanno-Youngs and Alan Rappeport
title: Torn Over Reopening Economy, Trump Says He Faces ‘Biggest Decision I’ve Ever Had to Make’
description: The president suggested he wanted to move soon, but he also promised to listen to public health officials cautioning against relaxing restrictions prematurely.
content: WASHINGTON — As he grapples simultaneously with the most devastating public health and economic crises of a lifetime, President Trump finds himself pulled in opposite directions on what to do next. The bankers, corporate executives and industrialists plead with him to reopen the country as soon as possible, while the medical experts beg for more time to curb the coronavirus.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mira Jacob
title: We Left New York With Clothes, Our Cat and Three Bottles of Disinfectant
description: A graphic short story of my family’s coronavirus journey across the country.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Julie Halpert
title: How to Manage Panic Attacks
description: The sudden, short-lived feeling of anxiety, shortness of breath and disabling fear can be confused with symptoms of coronavirus. Here’s what to do about it.
content: Anna Daniels, a 27-year-old living in Chagrin Falls, Ohio, was scheduled to start a new job as a nanny on March 30. But that has been put on hold indefinitely because of the coronavirus pandemic. She has been unemployed since the end of February. Ms. Daniels’s fiancé works for the local government and is considered an essential employee, so her days have been spent alone. It has taken a severe emotional toll.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Brianna Holt
title: Confessions of a Former Serial Dater
description: She met interesting people and developed vetting skills, but found her dating life improved once she “started to involve fewer people.”
content: The first time I was called a serial dater was by my roommate, after I admitted to her that I had two dates set up with two different guys on the same day. I remember being nervous that the first one wouldn’t end in time for the next. The second time was when my friend Nikki failed to invite me to her movie night because she assumed I already made plans to meet up with someone from a dating app.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Eric Lipton, David E. Sanger, Maggie Haberman, Michael D. Shear, Mark Mazzetti and Julian E. Barnes
title: He Could Have Seen What Was Coming: Behind Trump’s Failure on the Virus
description: An examination reveals the president was warned about the potential for a pandemic but that internal divisions, lack of planning and his faith in his own instincts led to a halting response.
content: WASHINGTON — “Any way you cut it, this is going to be bad,” a senior medical adviser at the Department of Veterans Affairs, Dr. Carter Mecher, wrote on the night of Jan. 28, in an email to a group of public health experts scattered around the government and universities. “The projected size of the outbreak already seems hard to believe.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Frank Bruni
title: A Politician Takes a Sledgehammer to His Own Ego
description: Just in time for Easter, the story of a blind state leader who is giving up his office to join the Jesuits.
content: In the market for Easter Sunday inspiration? Try the parable of the blind man who gave up political glory for Jesus Christ.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jason Horowitz and Elisabetta Povoledo
title: As They Console Coronavirus’s Victims, Italy’s Priests Are Dying, Too
description: Doctors and nurses on the front line have become symbols of sacrifice, but priests and nuns have also joined the fight, often at great risk.
content: ROME — On the Sunday before Easter, the priest’s phone rang.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Cecilia Gentili
title: What Lorena Borjas Did for the Trans Girls of Queens
description: She pushed us to shine authentically, to become a scream of subversion that says, “I am here, and I deserve happiness, too.”
content: As a Latina, physical touch and embraces are part of how I cope with the pain of grief. The coronavirus robs us of those touches, of that intimacy. I miss the tears of my friends touching my own face as we hold each other, breathing the same air in silent mourning, in place of answers we can’t give or have. In the past, my friend Lorena Borjas and I have grieved that way for others. The virus has now also taken that from me.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Brian Kaiser and Tiffany Hsu
title: Where Thousands of Masks a Day Are Decontaminated to Battle the Virus
description: A mask cleaning project inside shipping containers is part of  recent efforts to greatly increase the supply of equipment to health care workers.
content: Inside the rural Ohio labs run by Battelle, a nonprofit research and development firm, scientists have tested explosives, experimented with atomic energy and worked with chemical nerve agents. But some of the group’s most critical work is now happening outside, in a parking lot.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katharine Q. Seelye
title: Ruth B. Mandel, a Voice for Women in Politics, Dies at 81
description: Her experience fleeing the Nazis on the doomed “Voyage of the Damned” informed her faith in democracy as head of the Eagleton Institute of Politics.
content: Ruth B. Mandel was an infant when she and her parents fled Germany on the eve of World War II. They were among the 937 passengers, almost all of them Jewish refugees, aboard the ocean liner St. Louis on what was often called the Voyage of the Damned.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Johnny Diaz
title: Cities Close Streets to Cars, Opening Space for Social Distancing
description: Boston, Minneapolis, Oakland and other cities have temporarily banned through traffic on streets, giving pedestrians and cyclists extra elbow room during the coronavirus pandemic.
content: With roads cleared of traffic because of the coronavirus pandemic, some cities across the country have repurposed streets into car-free zones, giving pedestrians and cyclists extra room to spread out and practice social distancing.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dwight Garner
title: Plague Season, Through the Eyes of Writers
description: Step 1 from Kingsley Amis: Drink wine ‘in quantity.’
content: It was an uncertain spring.

author: By Eliza Shapiro
title: N.Y.C. Closes Schools for Academic Year, but Cuomo Says It’s His Decision
description: The mayor announced that in-person classes were suspended through June, but the governor countered that he had yet to make a call.
content: New York City’s public schools will remain closed through the end of the academic year because of the coronavirus, Mayor Bill de Blasio said on Saturday, confirming a disastrous scenario that he had previously warned of: more than three months of regular schooling for 1.1 million children would be lost.
source.name: The New York Times
